docs.text: What is Autism Autism, also known as Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), refers to a neurological difference that affects how individuals perceive, process, and interact with the world, and it is characterized by a diverse range of experiences, strengths, and challenges that are an integral part of the human experience. Your browser does not support the video tag. Autism is a unique way of experiencing the world—something some of us are born with. It helps us think differently, feel things differently, and see life from a fresh perspective. Even among people with Autism, these experiences can vary a lot. These differences can be a strength, offering new ideas and insights that make our communities richer. But they can also lead to challenges, especially when others don’t understand what we enjoy—or when we don’t understand what they enjoy. That doesn’t mean anyone is wrong—we’re just different. We can’t always change how others think, but we can learn ways to connect better with people who see the world differently. This website is here to support you in that journey. Being different isn’t always easy—but it can also be a beautiful and powerful thing. Helpful Links: The Autism Project For next steps and support. Website: https://theautismproject.org/ Phone: 401-785-2666 Address: 1516 Atwood Avenue | Johnston, RI 02919 🧠 What Is Autism? Autism, also called Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) , is a way some people’s brains work. It's not an illness — it just means your brain processes things like sounds, feelings, and conversations differently. People with autism might: 🗣️ Have a hard time talking with others or keeping a conversation going 🧍‍♂️🤝 Struggle to make or keep friendships 👀 Find it difficult to read body language, facial expressions, or tone of voice 🔁 Do the same things again and again (repeating movements or phrases) 👂👃 Be sensitive to lights, sounds, smells, or textures 🕓 Feel upset when routines or plans suddenly change 🧩 Have delayed language or different ways of learning and thinking If a few of these sound like you, you might be autistic . That’s okay! Knowing can help you understand yourself better — and help others support you in the way that works for your brain. 🧭 What to Do If You Think You Might Be Autistic ✅ Step 1: Talk to a Doctor Start by telling your doctor or a trusted adult (like a teacher, parent, or caregiver) how you feel. Ask if they can help you talk to a professional like: A psychologist A psychiatrist A neurologist These people are trained to help diagnose autism and understand how your brain works. 🧪 Step 2: Get an Evaluation An autism evaluation might include: Watching how you act and talk Asking about your childhood Testing how you think, solve problems, and use language Talking about how you handle daily life tasks Some people also get a neuropsychological evaluation , which helps figure out: 🧠 How you learn 🧩 How you solve problems 🧘 How you handle stress and emotions 🗂️ How you plan and organize This helps create a plan that supports your brain and learning style. 📍 Where to Get Evaluated in Rhode Island Here are trusted places in Rhode Island that can help with autism evaluations: Bradley Hospital – East Providence, RI Butler Hospital – Providence, RI Rhode Island Hospital – Providence, RI The Autism Project – Warwick, RI 🧱 What to Do While You Wait 🧑‍💻 Learn more about autism at Autism Self Advocacy Network 🤝 Join a community like Wrong Planet to meet others like you 📚 Read or watch stories about autistic people to hear real experiences 🗣️ Talk to someone you trust 🧭 What to Do After a Diagnosis Getting a diagnosis can feel like a big deal — but it’s a good step! Here’s what you can do next: 🧠 Build Your Support Network Talk to friends, family, or mentors who care about you Find a therapist or counselor if you want help with emotions or anxiety Ask for workplace or school support if you need it 🧰 Get Tools and Support Ask about accommodations at school or work Find helpful tools like planners, noise-canceling headphones, or fidgets Check out The Autism Project Rhode Island 💬 Learn to Advocate for Yourself You have the right to ask for what you need. It’s okay to say: "I need extra time on this." "Bright lights hurt my eyes." "I get overwhelmed by noise." ❤️ You Are Not Alone Autism is part of who you are. It can bring strengths like: Great memory Unique creativity Strong focus on things you love Honest and clear communication Asking for help doesn’t make you weak — it makes you smart. 📚 Works Cited & Helpful Links Autistic Self Advocacy Network (ASAN) Wrong Planet – Community for Autistic People Autism Speaks – What Is Autism? The Autism Project (RI) Bradley Hospital Butler Hospital Rhode Island Hospital 🧡 You are unique. You matter. Learning about your brain is a journey — and you don’t have to walk it alone.

docs.text: 📘 Finding and Keeping a Job You have skills and talents that employers value. Start by thinking about what you enjoy and what you are good at (for example, computers, art, animals, detail work, etc.). Search for jobs or internships that match these interests. When you find a job opening that looks good, don’t give up – try applying, and ask friends or family for help with the application if needed. Many autistic people succeed in jobs when they get the right supports. In Rhode Island, state agencies and non-profits can help you find work. For example, the RI Department of Behavioral Healthcare, Developmental Disabilities, and Hospitals (BHDDH) offers Employment Supports to help adults with disabilities find and keep jobs. The Office of Rehabilitation Services (ORS) can provide training and pre-employment services if you have an IEP or 504 plan. Use job coaching and training programs BHDDH describes several services: Job Development: Specialists help you look for jobs and apply Job Coaching: A coach helps you learn new tasks and communicate at work Job Retention: Help to keep and grow in your job once hired These supports are often temporary—they “fade out” once you learn the job. Local Rhode Island Programs Easterseals RI – EmploymentWORKS The Autism Project of RI AccessPoint RI Opportunities Unlimited (Middletown) National Supports Ticket to Work (SSI/SSDI Employment Training) Job Accommodation Network (JAN) – Free advice on workplace accommodations CareerOneStop – Workers with Disabilities WIPA – Benefits Counseling Under the ADA , employers must provide reasonable accommodations . This could include: Quiet workspace Written instructions Headphones Flexible scheduling If needed, talk to your boss or HR about what helps you work best. Transportation & Help at Work RIPTA RIde Paratransit – Door-to-door transit for people with disabilities Disability Rights Rhode Island (DRRI) – Free legal help & workplace advocacy 🎓 Succeeding in School You have the right to get help at school so you can learn your best. Under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) , schools must provide services for students with autism. You may qualify for an Individualized Education Program (IEP) with learning goals and supports (like therapy, tutoring, or tech tools). If you don’t qualify for an IEP, you may get a 504 Plan under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act . It can provide: Extra time on tests Help with note-taking Quiet seating options Speak Up for Your Needs You (and your family) can join your IEP or 504 meetings. You can practice saying things like: “I learn best with written instructions.” “I need a quiet space for tests.” If meetings feel stressful, RI schools offer facilitated IEP/504 meetings . According to the Autistic Self Advocacy Network (ASAN) , you have the right to use the communication method that works best for you , including written notes or devices. Useful School Accommodations Visual schedules or task checklists Breaks in quiet spaces Headphones for noise Fidget items Written and visual instructions Use planners or phone apps to stay organized. Talk to teachers or counselors when problems come up. If you are being bullied, tell a trusted adult —schools must keep you safe. Resources RIDE Special Education Hub Sherlock Center on Disabilities – Workshops for families and students 🌟 Quality of Life in Work and Public Places Take care of yourself outside of work and school too. This includes: Sleeping well Eating regularly Doing hobbies or calming activities Keeping a consistent routine Managing Sensory Needs In noisy, bright, or crowded places, it’s OK to: Wear headphones or sunglasses Use a fidget or calming object Take quiet breaks Ask a friend or coworker for help using a cue word or signal Some public spaces offer sensory-friendly options: Sensory-friendly movies (AMC Theaters & local RI cinemas) Quiet hours in stores Low-light performances Call ahead to ask if these options are available. Advocate for Yourself You have rights under the ADA . For example, you can say: “I’m autistic and need to wear headphones in loud spaces.” “Written instructions help me more than verbal ones.” Tips for Staying Calm Deep breathing Going outside for air Listening to music Using a calming app or routine Talking with a therapist (many specialize in autism) Local support groups and clinics include: The Autism Project Autism Society of Rhode Island DRRI – Disability Rights Rhode Island Sherlock Center on Disabilities Also explore inclusive programs like: Unified Sports – Special Olympics We Rock the Spectrum Gym (locations in nearby states) Celebrate small victories. Being autistic is a different way of experiencing the world—not a flaw. You deserve support, understanding, and success.

docs.text: Jobs & School Jobs and school are were a lot of us spend many hours of our day and knowing how to improve our quality of life there is very important. Finding a Job: Finding a job can be a challenging and overwhelming experience, but with the right strategies and support, it can also be a rewarding and empowering one. Here are some tips to help you find a job that's a good fit for you: Understanding Your Strengths and Interests Before starting your job search, take some time to think about your strengths, skills, and interests. What are you good at? What do you enjoy doing? What kind of work environment do you thrive in? Consider making a list of your strengths and interests to help you focus your job search. Exploring Job Options There are many different types of jobs out there, and it's essential to find one that aligns with your strengths, skills, and interests. Here are a few things to consider: What kind of work schedule do you prefer? (e.g., full-time, part-time, flexible hours) What kind of work environment do you thrive in? (e.g., quiet, busy, team-based) What kind of tasks and activities do you enjoy? (e.g., problem-solving, creative work, helping others) Creating a Resume and Cover Letter When applying for jobs, you'll typically need to submit a resume and cover letter. Here are some tips to help you create effective ones: Use clear and concise language Highlight your strengths and skills Tailor your resume and cover letter to each job you apply for Consider getting feedback from a career counselor or mentor Preparing for Interviews Interviews can be nerve-wracking, but with some preparation, you can feel more confident and prepared. Here are some tips: Research the company and the job position Practice answering common interview questions Consider bringing a support person or advocate with you to the interview Don't be afraid to ask for accommodations or support during the interview process Disclosing Your Autism Whether or not to disclose your autism to potential employers is a personal decision. Here are some things to consider: Disclosure can help you access accommodations and support Disclosure can also help you find an employer who is understanding and supportive However, disclosure is not required, and you have the right to keep your autism private Finding Support and Resources Finding a job can be a challenging and overwhelming experience, but you don't have to do it alone. Here are some resources that can help: Career counselors and job coaches Autism-specific job training programs Online resources and support groups Disability employment initiatives and programs Remember, finding a job takes time and effort, but with the right strategies and support, you can find a job that's a good fit for you. Don't be afraid to ask for help, and don't give up on your job search. You got this! Improving Your Quality of Life at Work: As an autistic person, you may face unique challenges in the workplace. However, with the right strategies and support, you can improve your quality of life at work and thrive in your career. Here are some tips to help you get started: Communicating Your Needs Communication is key to success in any workplace. As an autistic person, you may need to communicate your needs and preferences to your employer and colleagues. Here are some tips: Be open and honest about your autism and how it affects you Ask for accommodations and support when you need it Use clear and concise language to communicate your needs Consider using a communication plan or checklist to help you stay organized Managing Sensory Issues Sensory issues can be a major challenge in the workplace. Here are some tips to help you manage sensory issues: Identify your sensory triggers and develop strategies to avoid or cope with them Use sensory-friendly tools and equipment, such as noise-cancelling headphones or a weighted blanket Take regular breaks to rest and recharge Consider working from home or in a quiet space if possible Building Positive Relationships Building positive relationships with your colleagues and employer is crucial to success in the workplace. Here are some tips: Be respectful and professional in your interactions with others Use active listening skills to understand and respond to others Ask questions and seek feedback to improve your relationships Consider joining a social group or club to meet new people and build connections Managing Stress and Anxiety Stress and anxiety can be major challenges in the workplace. Here are some tips to help you manage stress and anxiety: Identify your stress triggers and develop strategies to cope with them Use relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation, to calm yourself Take regular breaks to rest and recharge Consider seeking support from a mental health professional if needed Advocating for Yourself As an autistic person, you may need to advocate for yourself in the workplace. Here are some tips: Know your rights and responsibilities under the law Be confident and assertive in your interactions with others Use "I" statements to express your needs and feelings Consider bringing a support person or advocate with you to meetings or discussions Finding Support and Resources Finally, don't forget to seek out support and resources to help you succeed in the workplace. docs.text: Meditation Meditation is helpfull for making you feel more regulated. Try the one in the video below. Guided Forest Walk Your browser does not support the video tag. Welcome to the Forest Walk Meditation Welcome to this forest walk meditation, where you can take a few moments to breathe, relax, and connect with nature. Find a comfortable and quiet space to sit or lie down, and take a deep breath in through your nose and out through your mouth. Imagining the Forest Imagine yourself standing at the edge of a forest, surrounded by tall trees that stretch up towards the sky. Notice the sensation of your feet touching the ground, and the feeling of the air on your skin. Take a deep breath in, and smell the scent of the trees and the earth. Walking into the Forest As you begin to walk into the forest, notice the sounds around you. Listen to the birds singing, the rustling of leaves, and the gentle breeze moving through the trees. Allow these sounds to wash over you, and feel your body begin to relax. Grounding and Centering Notice the sensation of your feet touching the ground with each step. Feel the weight of your body distributed evenly, and the connection to the earth beneath you. With each step, allow yourself to feel more grounded and centered. Focusing on the Breath As you walk, bring your attention to your breath. Notice the sensation of the air moving in and out of your body, and the rise and fall of your chest. Allow your breath to become slow and deep, and feel your body begin to calm. Releasing Anxiety and Stress Now, imagine that with each step, you are leaving behind any feelings of anxiety, stress, or overwhelm. Allow these feelings to drop away, like leaves falling from the trees. With each step, feel yourself becoming more calm, more centered, and more regulated. Feeling the Sun's Warmth As you continue to walk, notice the sensation of the sun on your skin. Feel its warmth and gentle touch, and allow it to soothe any areas of tension or discomfort. Imagine that the sun's warmth is filling your body, and helping you to feel more relaxed and at ease. Safety and Support Remember, you are safe and supported in this forest. Allow yourself to let go of any worries or concerns, and simply be present in this moment. Take a deep breath in, and feel your body fill with calm and relaxation. The Clearing As you come to a clearing, notice the sensation of the space around you. Feel the openness and freedom, and allow yourself to expand and relax. Imagine that you are a part of this forest, connected to the trees, the earth, and the sky. Conclusion Take a few more deep breaths, and allow yourself to settle into this feeling of calm and regulation. Remember that you can return to this forest whenever you need to, and that it will always be here to support and comfort you. Returning to the Present When you are ready, slowly begin to bring your attention back to your physical body. Notice the sensation of your feet touching the ground, and the feeling of the air on your skin. Take a deep breath in, and slowly open your eyes. Remember to take this feeling of calm and regulation with you, and to return to it whenever you need to. Forest Sounds Your browser does not support the video tag. docs.text: Health Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants. -Michael Pollan Why Gut Matters Many autistic adults experience gastrointestinal (GI) issues like constipation, bloating, or diarrhea. Taking care of your gut can improve comfort, focus, mood, and energy. Hydration: The First Step to Gut Health Why it matters: Water helps food move smoothly through your gut. Daily goal: Aim for 6-8 cups (or more if you are being active or feeling hot) Tips: Carry a water bottle. Flavor water with fruit or herbs. Try herbal teas or seltzer if plain water is hard to drink Fiber: For Regular Bowel Movements What it does: Helps prevent constipation and feeds good gut bacteria. Daily goal: 25-30g of fiber. Fiber-rich foods: Fruits (berries, pears, apples with skin) Vegetables (broccoli, carrots, leafy greens) Whole grains (oats, brown rice, quinoa) Beans, lentils, and seeds (chia, flaxseed) Go slow: Increase fiber gradually and drink more water. Healthy Fats: Calm the Gut & Brain Why they help: Support brain and gut function, reduce inflammation. Sources: Avocados Olive Oil Fatty Fish (salmon, sardines) Nuts & seeds (Walnuts, flax, chia) Magnesium: Soothing Mineral for Gut & Mood Why it helps: Can ease constipation, support relaxation, and reduce anxiety. Sources: Pumpkin seeds, almonds, cashews Spinach, black beans Whole grains (brown rice, oatmeal) Supplements: Magnesium citrate is gentle on the stomach and may relieve constipation - check with Registered Dietitian or Doctor first. Vitamin C: Antioxidant & Gentle Support Why it helps: Supports the immune and may ease mild constipation. Sources: Oranges, strawberries, kiwi Bell peppers, tomatoes, broccoli Supplements: Powders or chewables are easy options, ask your Registered Dietitian or Doctor about your best dose. Supplements to Consider for Gut Support Check with your healthcare provider before starting any supplement. These can be helpful for many autistic adults with sensitive GI systems: Probiotics What they do: Add "good" bacteria to support gut balance. Tips: Choose multi-strain formulas. Yogurt and kefir also contain live cultures. Aloe Vera Juice What it may help with: Mild constipation, gut inflammation, and soothing the digestive lining. Tip: Look for decolorized, purified aloe vera juice (without aloin). Start with a small amount (1-2 oz/day). Digestive Enzymes What they do: Help break down food more effectively and reduce bloating or discomfort. When to use: Take with meals, especially if you notice symptoms after eating certain foods (like dairy, gluten, or high-fat meals). Final Tips Routine helps: Try eating meals at the same time each day. Textures matter: Choose foods that feel comfortable to eat. Start small: Add one new habit at a time. Track symptoms: Keep a food and gut journal if helpful. When to Get Help If you're having ongoing stomach pain, constipation, or discomfort, talk to a doctor or registered dietitian for personalized support. Megan Martin, RDN, LDN

docs.text: Social Skills & The Community Social Skills Do you ever feel overwhelmed in social situations? Maybe the lights are too bright, the noise is too loud, or you're just not sure what to do. Well, today we're going to learn a simple trick to help you feel more comfortable and confident in social situations. It's called S.E.A. Supplement The "S" in S.E.A stands for Supplement. This means that if you need something to help you feel more comfortable, you can use a supplement. For example, if the room is too bright, you can wear sunglasses. If it's too loud, you can wear earplugs. And if it's too cold, you can wear a sweater. It's like having a special tool to help you feel better. Exit The "E" in S.E.A stands for Exit. If you're feeling really overwhelmed and you can't use a supplement to help, it's okay to exit the situation. This means you can quietly get up and leave the room. It's like taking a break to recharge and come back when you're feeling better. Ask The "A" in S.E.A stands for Ask. You can always ask for for help. (example: "Could you turn down the lights?") If you're not sure what to do in a social situation, you can ask them a question about themselves, like "What's your favorite hobby?" or "What do you like to do for fun?" This can help you feel more comfortable and start a conversation. Example scenario Let's say you're at a birthday party and it's really loud. You can use your earplugs (Supplement) to block out the noise. But if it's still too much, you can quietly get up and leave the room (Exit), or you could ask if the music could be turned down (Ask). And if you're not sure what to do once you are more compfortable at the party, you can ask someone a question, like "What's your favorite game?" (Ask). Conclusion So, remember the S.E.A acronym: Supplement, Exit, and Ask. It's like having a special toolbox to help you feel more comfortable and confident in social situations. Just remember to use your supplements, exit when you need to, and ask for help when you're not sure what to do. You got this! docs.text: S.E.A. Framework: Navigating Social and Sensory Situations Introduction Navigating social situations can be tough—especially if lights are too bright, sounds are too loud, or you're unsure how to respond. This is okay. You’re not alone. The S.E.A. strategy can help: it stands for Supplement , Exit , and Ask —three steps you can take to feel more in control and comfortable in public or social spaces. 🧰 Supplement What it means: Use helpful tools to manage your sensory environment. Examples: - Sunglasses to block bright lights - Noise-canceling headphones or earplugs for loud sounds - Fidget tools to stay calm and focused Why it helps: Using sensory supports can lower stress and help you stay in a situation without getting overwhelmed. These are not "cheats"—they're smart tools. Read more about sensory strategies from the National Autistic Society. 🚪 Exit What it means: Leave the situation or take a break if things feel too intense. Examples: - Step outside for some quiet - Use a quiet room or space if available - Let someone know you’re taking a break Why it helps: Breaks can stop overwhelm before it gets worse. You're allowed to take space when you need it. Learn how quiet spaces can support autistic individuals. 🗣️ Ask What it means: Ask for what you need or ask a question to start a conversation. Examples: - “Can we turn the lights down?” - “Can I have a break?” - “What’s your favorite game?” to start talking with someone new Why it helps: Asking helps people understand your needs—and gives you a way to take control of the situation. Tips on teaching and practicing self-advocacy from Autism Speaks. Example Scenario You’re at a birthday party and it’s really loud. Try Supplement : Put on your headphones. If that’s not enough, use Exit : Step outside for a few minutes. Then try Ask : “Can we lower the music a little?” or “What’s your favorite part of the party?” Helpful Tools These supports can make social situations easier: Visual Schedules : Show what’s happening and when Emotion Cards : Help you explain how you feel Social Stories: Short stories about how to handle situations Conclusion The S.E.A. framework gives you three steps: Supplement — Use tools like headphones or fidgets Exit — Take a break when needed Ask — Speak up or start a conversation Practice using these steps and you’ll feel more confident in social settings. You are allowed to take care of yourself. You’ve got this! Works Cited National Autistic Society – Occupational Therapy and Sensory Strategies The Autism Helper – Creating Quiet Break Areas Autism Speaks – Teaching Your Child Self-Advocacy National Autistic Society – Visual Supports Raising Children Network – Emotions for Autistic Children

docs.text: What it means: Use helpful tools to manage your sensory environment. Examples: - Sunglasses to block bright lights - Noise-canceling headphones or earplugs for loud sounds - Fidget tools to stay calm and focused Why it helps: Using sensory supports can lower stress and help you stay in a situation without getting overwhelmed. These are not "cheats"—they're smart tools. Read more about sensory strategies from the National Autistic Society.
docs.title: 🧰 Supplement

docs.text: What it means: Leave the situation or take a break if things feel too intense. Examples: - Step outside for some quiet - Use a quiet room or space if available - Let someone know you’re taking a break Why it helps: Breaks can stop overwhelm before it gets worse. You're allowed to take space when you need it. Learn how quiet spaces can support autistic individuals.
docs.title: 🚪 Exit

docs.text: What it means: Ask for what you need or ask a question to start a conversation. Examples: - “Can we turn the lights down?” - “Can I have a break?” - “What’s your favorite game?” to start talking with someone new Why it helps: Asking helps people understand your needs—and gives you a way to take control of the situation. Tips on teaching and practicing self-advocacy from Autism Speaks.
docs.title: 🗣️ Ask

docs.text: You’re at a birthday party and it’s really loud. Try Supplement : Put on your headphones. If that’s not enough, use Exit : Step outside for a few minutes. Then try Ask : “Can we lower the music a little?” or “What’s your favorite part of the party?”
docs.title: Example Scenario

docs.text: These supports can make social situations easier: Visual Schedules : Show what’s happening and when Emotion Cards : Help you explain how you feel Social Stories: Short stories about how to handle situations
docs.title: Helpful Tools

docs.text: The S.E.A. framework gives you three steps: Supplement — Use tools like headphones or fidgets Exit — Take a break when needed Ask — Speak up or start a conversation Practice using these steps and you’ll feel more confident in social settings. You are allowed to take care of yourself. You’ve got this!

docs.text: What is Stimming? Stimming, also known as self-stimulatory behavior, is when someone does repetitive movements or actions to help themselves feel calm, relaxed, or focused. Examples of stimming include hand flapping, rocking, spinning, or repeating certain words or sounds. Why Do People Stimm? People with autism or other neurodiverse conditions might stimm because it helps them: Deal with overwhelming feelings or sensations Block out too much noise or stress Focus on a task or activity Express excitement or joy Is Stimming Bad? No, stimming is not bad. It's a natural way for some people to cope with their feelings and surroundings. However, some stimming behaviors might be distracting or disruptive in certain situations, like in a classroom or at work. Good Alternatives to Stimming If you're looking for alternative ways to cope with your feelings or focus, here are some ideas: Deep breathing exercises Drawing or coloring Listening to music or nature sounds Playing with a stress ball or fidget toy Going for a walk or doing some light exercise Practicing yoga or meditation Finding What Works for You Everyone is different, so it's essential to find what works best for you. You might need to try a few different alternatives to see what helps you feel calm, focused, or happy. Remember, it's okay to stimm, and it's also okay to find other ways to cope. Tips for Family and Friends If you're supporting someone who stims, here are some tips: Be patient and understanding Don't try to stop them from stimming, as this can be stressful Encourage them to find alternative coping mechanisms Offer support and acceptance Help them find a safe and comfortable space to stimm if needed Helpfull Links Coloringus.com (coloring pages to print)
